title: Fraction Equivalence and Comparison

vocab.definition: Fractions that represent the same value but have different numerators and denominators
The same denominator used in two or more fractions to compare them
Common fractions like 1/2, 1/4, 3/4 used to estimate and compare
To write a fraction in its simplest form using the smallest possible numbers
The top number in a fraction that counts how many parts
The bottom number in a fraction that tells the total equal parts
The largest number that divides both the numerator and denominator
The smallest multiple shared by two or more numbers
A method to compare fractions by multiplying across the numerators and denominators

teachingNotes: Use fraction strips and number lines. Focus on visual models before abstract algorithms. Practice finding equivalent fractions through multiplication and division.

sample.question: Show on a number line where 1/2 and 2/4 are.
What is a common denominator for 2/3 and 5/6?

truefalse.question: To compare fractions with different denominators, you need a common denominator.
Multiplying the numerator and denominator by the same number changes the value of a fraction.
Cross-multiplying can help compare fractions with unlike denominators.
Equivalent fractions name the same point on a number line.
